facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment dated September 21, 1959, of the Punjab High Court in Civil Writ No. 1050 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment dated September 21, 1959, of the Punjab High Court, Chandigarh, in Civil Writ No. 1050 of 1959.

facts.text: Punjab High Court summarily dismissed the petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We have stated that the petition was summarily dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: Special leave obtained from Supreme Court on August 19, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: An application for a certificate of fitness having failed in the High Court, the appellant asked for and obtained special leave from this Court. on August 19, 1960.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 5, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. December 5.

facts.text: Appellant claimed five persons (respondents 2 to 6) not qualified under Art. 233 for appointment as District Judges.

facts.text: Three respondents (Shamsher Bahadur, Gurdev Singh, Hans Raj Khanna) had names on Roll of Advocates of Punjab High Court before appointment as District Judges.

anchor.surface_text: It would thus appear that of the five respondents mentioned above, three, namely, Shamshere Bahadur, Gurudev Singh and Hans Raj Khanna had their names on the Roll of Advocates of the Punjab High Court before they were appointed as District Judges.

facts.text: Two respondents (Harbans Singh, P.R. Sawhney) did not have names on Roll at time of appointment as District Judges.

anchor.surface_text: Two of them, Harbans Singh and P. R. Sawhney, did number have their names factually on the Roll when they were appointed as District Judges.

facts.text: Court held all respondents 2-6 eligible under Art. 233(2) as they had been advocates for not less than seven years.

anchor.surface_text: They were clearly eligible for appointment under cl. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution.

facts.text: High Courts (Punjab) Order, 1947 established High Court for East Punjab from August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: the Governor-General made the High Courts  Punjab  Order, 1947, which established as from the appointed day  August 15, 1947  a High Court of Judicature for the then Province of East Punjab.

facts.text: Clause 6 of High Courts (Punjab) Order, 1947 recognized Lahore High Court advocates as entitled to practise in East Punjab High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that, subject to any rule made or direction given by the High Court of East Punjab in the exercise of the powers companyferred by this Article, any person who, immediately before the appointed day, is an advocate, vakil or attorney entitled to practise in the High Court at Lahore shall be recognised as an advocate, vakil or attorney entitled to practise in the High Court of East Punjab.

facts.text: Bar Councils Act, 1926 sections 3-16 came into force for East Punjab High Court on September 28, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated September 28, 1948, the Governor of East Punjab directed that the provisions of ss. 3 to 16 of the said Act shall companye into force

That clause lays down that a person number already in the service of the Union or of the State shall only be eligible to be appointed a district judge if  1  he has been for number less than seven years an advocate or, a pleader and  2  is recommended by the High Court for appointment.

issues.text: Whether 'advocate or pleader' in Article 233(2) includes only those entitled to practise in courts in India excluding advocates of foreign courts like pre-partition Lahore High Court

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the appellant has companytended that respondents 2 to 6 did number fulfil the requirement of having been seven years an advocate or pleader and has put his argument in support of his companytention in the following way. Firstly, he has submitted that the expression advocate or pleader is an expression of legal import and must be given its generally accepted meaning at the time the Constitution was adopted and that expression according to learned Counsel means an advocate or pleader entitled to appear and plead for another in a Court in India, but does number include an advocate or pleader of a foreign Court for this submission he has relied on the definition of the expression legal practitioners in the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879  XVIII of 1879  of pleader in the Civil Procedure Code,

Articles 124 and 217 are differently worded and refer to an additional qualification of citizenship which is number a requirement of Art., 233, and we do number think that el.  2  of Art. 233 can be interpreted in the light of Explanations added to Arts. 124 and 217.

anchor.surface_text: We companysider that even if we proceed on the footing that both these persons were recruited from the Bar and their appointment has to be tested by the requirements of el.  2 , we must hold that they fulfilled those requirements. They were Advocates enrolled in the Lahore High Court this is number disputed. Under cl. 6 of the High Courts  Punjab  Order, 1947, they were recognised as Advocates entitled to practise in the Punjab High Court till the Bar Councils Act, 1926, came into force. Under s. 8  2  a  of that Act it was the duty of the High Court to prepare and maintain a roll of advocates in which their names should have been entered on the day on which s 8 came into force, that is, on September 28, 1948.

arguments.claim: Proviso to s.8(2) Bar Councils Act requiring Rs.10 fee does not take away automatic right to roll entry under s.8(2)(a)

holdings.text: Respondents 2 to 6 fulfilled the requirements of clause 2 of Article 233 and were eligible for appointment as District Judges.

anchor.surface_text: but the point for decision is a narrow one and depends on whether respondents 2 to 6 fulfilled the requirements of cl. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution when they were appointed as District Judges by respondent 1. That clause lays down that a person not already in the service of the Union or of the State shall only be eligible to be appointed a district judge if (i) he has been for not less than seven years an advocate or, a pleader and (ii) is recommended by the High Court for appointment. ... They were clearly eligible for appointment under cl. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All had more than seven years standing as advocates/pleaders, including pre-partition practice in Lahore High Court, recognized under relevant laws; recommended by High Court.

holdings.text: Pre-partition practice in Lahore High Court counts towards the seven years standing under Article 233(2).

anchor.surface_text: Even if we assume without finally pronouncing on their correctness that learned Counsel is right in his first two submissions... holdings.reasoning_summary: Standing preserved by Clause 6 High Courts (Punjab) Order 1947 and s.8 Bar Councils Act; policy avoids seven-year ineligibility gap post-partition.

holdings.text: The expression 'has been' in Article 233(2) does not strictly require the person to be an enrolled advocate at the exact time of appointment if previously qualified and recognized.

anchor.surface_text: Even if we assume without finally pronouncing on their correctness that learned Counsel is right in his first two submissions, viz., that the word advocate in cl. 2 of Art. 233 means an advocate of a Court in India and the appointee must be such an advocate at the time of his appointment, no objection on those grounds can be raised to the appointment of three of the respondents who were factually on the roll of Advocates of the Punjab High Court at the time of their appointment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed arguendo; three were on roll, others recognized; grammar not rigidly applied in constitutional interpretation.

holdings.text: 'Advocate or pleader' under Article 233(2) includes those recognized from pre-partition Lahore High Court, not limited to current Indian court practitioners.

anchor.surface_text: Even if we assume without finally pronouncing on their correctness that learned Counsel is right in his first two submissions, viz., that the word advocate in cl. 2 of Art. 233 means an advocate of a Court in India... no objection on those grounds can be raised.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed arguendo but irrelevant as rights preserved by High Courts Order and Bar Councils Act; statutory definitions not controlling.

holdings.text: Harbans Singh and P.R. Sawhney fulfilled Article 233(2) despite names not factually on roll at appointment, as automatically entitled under prior recognition and Bar Councils Act s.8(2)(a).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Recognized under cl.6 High Courts Order till Bar Councils Act; automatic roll entry duty of High Court; Rs.10 fee proviso does not divest right.

holdings.text: No statutory service rules contravened by the appointments, as no clear proof of breach provided.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Petitioner failed to identify or prove violation of any particular statutory rule.

holdings.text: Strict grammatical interpretation of 'has been' not necessarily binding in constitutional provisions (obiter).

anchor.surface_text: It is perhaps necessary to add that we must not be understood to have decided that the expression has been must always mean what learned Counsel for the appellant says it means according to the strict rules of grammar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assumed arguendo; constitutional interpretation not strictly grammatical; examples from other Articles.

holdings.text: Explanations in Articles 124 and 217 not applicable to interpret Article 233 (obiter).

anchor.surface_text: Articles 124 and 217 are differently worded and refer to an additional qualification of citizenship which is not a requirement of Art. 233, and we do not think that cl. 2 of Art. 233 can be interpreted in the light of Explanations added to Arts. 124 and 217.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 233 self-contained; different context and wording.

holdings.text: Alternative argument under s.4 Legal Practitioners Act unnecessary to decide (obiter).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Decision rests on other grounds; no need to examine.

anchor.surface_text: They also had the necessary standing of seven years to be eligible, under el. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution. These conclusions really dispose of the appeal. We may state, however, that an alternative argument based on s. 4 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879, was also presented before us on behalf of these respondents. The argument was that the respondents having been enrolled as advocates in the Lahore High Court were entitled to practise in any subordinate Court in India, and that right was not taken away even after the Lahore High Court ceased to be a High Court in the territory of India under the Constitution.

edges.explanation: Argument that Art.233 is self-contained and explanations in Arts.124/217 not applicable directly grounds the holding that those explanations do not apply to interpret Art.233.
The Legal Practitioners Act 1879 definition of legal practitioners supports the holding's expansive interpretation including pre-partition Lahore High Court advocates.
The definition of legal practitioners under the 1879 Act addresses the interpretive question in the issue regarding inclusion of pre-partition foreign court advocates.
The CPC pleader definition supports the broad holding on inclusion under Article 233(2).
The CPC pleader definition addresses the scope of 'pleader' relevant to the issue on Article 233(2).

The Bar Councils Act 1926 definition of advocate supports the holding's expansive interpretation including pre-partition Lahore High Court advocates, as the Act predates partition and applied across relevant territories.

anchor.surface_text: urt of undivided Punjab. The Independence Act, 1947, brought into existence two independent Dominions- India and Pakistan-and s. 9 thereof gave the Go

edges.explanation: The definition of advocate under Bar Councils Act 1926 addresses the core question in the issue regarding the scope of 'advocate or pleader' in Article 233(2).
Fact of High Court establishment on August 15, 1947 grounds the argument distinguishing pre-partition practice under Art.233(2), as it marks the relevant temporal boundary.
By overruling the maintainability objection and mandating a decision on the legality of appointments, holding h1 supports the continued relevance and application of the writ of quo warranto concept.
Holding h1 directly overrules the preliminary objection to the maintainability of the appeal, which is the core of issue i1.

anchor.surface_text: On a careful consideration of the matter, we have come to the conclusion that the preliminary objection must be overruled and in the circumstances of this case, this Court must decide on the legality of the impugned appointments.

They also had the necessary standing of seven years to be eligible, under el. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution. These conclusions really dispose of the appeal. We may state, however, that an alternative argument based on s. 4 of the Legal Practitioners Act, 1879, was also presented before us on behalf of these respondents. The argument was that the respondents having been enrolled as advocates in the Lahore High Court were entitled to practise in any subordinate Court in India, and that right was not taken away even after the Lahore High Court ceased to be a High Court in the territory of India under the Constitution.

edges.explanation: Holding deems alternative argument under s.4 (matching the issue of entitlement under section 4 post-Lahore High Court cessation) unnecessary to decide

anchor.surface_text: but the point for decision is a narrow one and depends on whether respondents 2 to 6 fulfilled the requirements of cl. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution when they were appointed as District Judges by respondent 1. That clause lays down that a person not already in the service of the Union or of the State shall only be eligible to be appointed a district judge if (i) he has been for not less than seven years an advocate or, a pleader and (ii) is recommended by the High Court for appointment. ... They were clearly eligible for appointment under cl. 2 of Art. 233 of the Constitution.

The argument was that the respondents having been enrolled as advocates in the Lahore High Court were entitled to practise in any subordinate Court in India, and that right was not taken away even after the Lahore High Court ceased to be a High Court in the territory of India under the Constitution.

Even if we assume without finally pronouncing on their correctness that learned Counsel is right in his first two submissions, viz., that the word advocate in cl. 2 of Art. 233 means an advocate of a Court in India and the appointee must be such an advocate at the time of his appointment, no objection on those grounds can be raised to the appointment of three of the respondents who were factually on the roll of Advocates of the Punjab High Court at the time of their appointment.

edges.explanation: The holding directly resolves the issue by holding that 'advocate or pleader' under Article 233(2) includes advocates recognized from pre-partition Lahore High Court and is not limited to current Indian court practitioners.

edges.explanation: Issue i1 explicitly references the 'writ of quo warranto' in questioning the maintainability of the appeal when respondents no longer hold the office.
The issue concerns the scope of 'advocate or pleader' in Article 233(2), which relates to the definition of legal practitioners under the Legal Practitioners Act 1879.
The issue concerns the interpretation of 'pleader', directly addressing the CPC definition.
Resolving the issue requires reference to the CPC pleader definition.
